definitions.definition: At, near or towards the front of something.
examples: She was sitting well forward in the railway carriage.
The bus driver told everyone standing up to move forward .

subdefinitions.definition: At, near, or towards the bow of a vessel (with the frame of reference within the vessel).

definitions.definition: In the direction in which someone or something is facing.
examples: I leant forward to get a better look.
The grandfather clock toppled forward and crashed to the ground.

definitions.definition: In the desired or usual direction of movement or progress, physically or figuratively; onwards .
examples: After spending an hour stuck in the mud, we could once again move forward .
Wind the film forward a few frames.
Don't forget to put the clocks forward by one hour tonight!
We need to move this project forward .

definitions.definition: So that front and back are in the usual orientation.
examples: Don't wear your baseball cap backward; turn it forward .

definitions.definition: In the usual order or sequence.
examples: A palindrome reads the same backward as forward .
From this day forward , there will be no more brussels sprouts at the cafeteria.

definitions.definition: To an earlier point in time. See also bring forward .
examples: The meeting has been moved forward an hour. It was at 3 o'clock; now it's at 2 o'clock.

main_definition: At, near or towards the front of something.
secondary_definitions: In the direction in which someone or something is facing.
In the desired or usual direction of movement or progress, physically or figuratively; onwards .
So that front and back are in the usual orientation.
In the usual order or sequence.
To an earlier point in time. See also bring forward .
